The main functions treated in this chapter are first the Coulomb radial functions F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) ( ( ) ), which are used in the case of repulsive Coulomb interactions, and secondly the functions f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) , h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) , s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) , c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) ( ( ) ), which are used in the case of attractive Coulomb interactions.

This differential equation has a regular singularity at \rho=0 with indices \ell+1 and -\ell , and an irregular singularity of rank 1 at \rho=\infty (§§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.RS, LABEL:sec:AS.DE.IS).
There are two turning points, that is, points at which \ifrac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}\rho}^{2}}=0 (§LABEL:sec:AS.DEWP.CC).
The outer one is given by \rho_{\mathrm{tp}}\left(\eta,\ell\right)=\eta+(\eta^{2}+\ell(\ell+1))^{1/2}.

The function F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) is recessive (§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.LGA) at \rho=0 , and is defined by F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)2^{-\ell-1}(\mp\mathrm {i})^{\ell+1}M_{\pm\mathrm{i}\eta,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(\pm 2\mathrm{i}\rho \right), or equivalently F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)\rho^{\ell+1}e^{\mp \mathrm{i}\rho}M\left(\ell+1\mp\mathrm{i}\eta,2\ell+2,\pm 2\mathrm{i}\rho \right), where M_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right) and M\left(a,b,z\right) are defined in §§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.DE.WH and LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU, and C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)=\frac{2^{\ell}e^{-\pi\eta/2}|\Gamma\left(\ell+1+ \mathrm{i}\eta\right)|}{(2\ell+1)!}.
The choice of ambiguous signs in (LABEL:eq:CW.SOL.REG1) and (LABEL:eq:CW.SOL.REG2) is immaterial, provided that either all upper signs are taken, or all lower signs are taken.
This is a consequence of Kummer’s transformation (§LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DF.CO).
F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) is a real and analytic function of \rho on the open interval 0<\rho<\infty , and also an analytic function of \eta when -\infty<\eta<\infty.

The normalizing constant C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right) is always positive, and has the alternative form C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)=\dfrac{2^{\ell}\left((2\pi\eta/(e^{2\pi\eta}-1)) \prod_{k=1}^{\ell}(\eta^{2}+k^{2})\right)^{\ifrac{1}{2}}}{(2\ell+1)!}.

The functions {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) are defined by {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=(\mp\mathrm{i})^{\ell}e^{(\pi\eta/2)\pm \mathrm{i}{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right)}W_{\mp\mathrm{i}\eta,\ell+\frac{1}{ 2}}\left(\mp 2\mathrm{i}\rho\right), or equivalently {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=e^{\pm\mathrm{i}{\theta_{\ell}}\left( \eta,\rho\right)}(\mp 2\mathrm{i}\rho)^{\ell+1\pm\mathrm{i}\eta}U\left(\ell+1 \pm\mathrm{i}\eta,2\ell+2,\mp 2\mathrm{i}\rho\right), where W_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right) , U\left(a,b,z\right) are defined in §§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.DE.WH and LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU, {\theta_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=\rho-\eta\ln\left(2\rho\right)-\tfrac{1} {2}\ell\pi+{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right), and {\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right)=\operatorname{ph}\Gamma\left(\ell+1+\mathrm{i }\eta\right), the branch of the phase in (LABEL:eq:CW.SOL.SG2) being zero when \eta=0 and continuous elsewhere.
{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right) is the Coulomb phase shift.

{H^{+}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) and {H^{-}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) are complex conjugates, and their real and imaginary parts are given by {H^{+}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)+\mathrm{i} F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right), {H^{-}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)=G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right)-\mathrm{i} F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right).
As in the case of F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , the solutions {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) and G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) are analytic functions of \rho when 0<\rho<\infty.
Also, e^{\mp\mathrm{i}{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right)}{H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta, \rho\right) are analytic functions of \eta when -\infty<\eta<\infty.
With arguments \eta,\rho suppressed, \mathscr{W}\left\{G_{\ell},F_{\ell}\right\}=\mathscr{W}\left\{{H^{\pm}_{\ell}} ,F_{\ell}\right\}=1.

Then, by application of the results given in §§LABEL:sec:AS.DEWP.CII andLABEL:sec:AS.DEWP.CIII, two sets of asymptotic expansions can be constructed for F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) and G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) when \eta\to\infty.
The first set is in terms of Airy functions and the expansions are uniform for fixed \ell and \delta\leq z<\infty , where \delta is an arbitrary small positive constant.
They would include the results of §LABEL:sec:CW.AE.TP as a special case.

The second set is in terms of Bessel functions of orders 2\ell+1 and 2\ell+2 , and they are uniform for fixed \ell and 0\leq z\leq 1-\delta , where \delta again denotes an arbitrary small positive constant.
Compare also §LABEL:sec:CW.AErep.UAE.

The functions F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , and {H^{\pm}_{\ell}}\left(\eta,\rho\right) may be extended to noninteger values of \ell by generalizing (2\ell+1)!=\Gamma\left(2\ell+2\right ), and supplementing (LABEL:eq:CW.PRHO.IS1) by a formula derived from (LABEL:eq:CW.SOL.IR2) with U\left(a,b,z\right) expanded via (LABEL:eq:CH.MU.DF.C2).
These functions may also be continued analytically to complex values of \rho , \eta , and \ell.

The quantities C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right) , {\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right) , and R_{\ell} , given by (LABEL:eq:CW.SOL.CA), (LABEL:eq:CW.SOL.SG2), and (LABEL:eq:CW.RR.RR1), respectively, must be defined consistently so that C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)=2^{\ell}e^{\mathrm{i}{\sigma_{\ell}}\left(\eta\right )-(\pi\eta/2)}\Gamma\left(\ell+1-\mathrm{i}\eta\right)/\Gamma\left(2\ell+2 \right), and R_{\ell}=(2\ell+1)C_{\ell}\left(\eta\right)/C_{\ell-1}\left(\eta\right).
For further information see ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

Another parametrization of (LABEL:eq:CW.EQ.EQ) is given by \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}r}^{2}}+\left(\epsilon+\frac{2}{r}-\frac{ \ell(\ell+1)}{r^{2}}\right)w=0, where r=-\eta\rho, \epsilon=1/\eta^{2}.
Again, there is a regular singularity at r=0 with indices \ell+1 and -\ell , and an irregular singularity of rank 1 at r=\infty.
When \epsilon>0 the outer turning point is given by r_{\mathrm{tp}}\left(\epsilon,\ell\right)=\left(\sqrt{1+\epsilon\ell(\ell+1)}- 1\right)\Bigm{/}\epsilon; compare (LABEL:eq:CW.EQ.TP).

The function f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is recessive (§LABEL:sec:AS.DE.LGA) at r=0 , and is defined by f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=\kappa^{\ell+1}M_{\kappa,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left( 2r/\kappa\right)/(2\ell+1)!, or equivalently f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=(2r)^{\ell+1}e^{-r/\kappa}M\left(\ell+1-\kappa,2 \ell+2,2r/\kappa\right)/{(2\ell+1)!} , where M_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right) and M\left(a,b,z\right) are defined in§§LABEL:sec:CH.KM.DE.WH and LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DE.KU, and \kappa=\begin{cases}(-\epsilon)^{-1/2},&\epsilon<0,r>0,\\ -(-\epsilon)^{-1/2},&\epsilon<0,r<0,\\ \pm\mathrm{i}\epsilon^{-1/2},&\epsilon>0.\end{cases } The choice of sign in the last line of (LABEL:eq:CW.SOLrep.KAP) is immaterial: the same function f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is obtained. This is a consequence of Kummer’s transformation (§LABEL:sec:CH.MU.DF.CO).
f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is real and an analytic function of r in the interval -\infty<r<\infty , and it is also an analytic function of \epsilon when -\infty<\epsilon<\infty.
This includes \epsilon=0 , hence f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) can be expanded in a convergent power series in \epsilon in a neighborhood of \epsilon=0 (§LABEL:sec:CW.AErep.RS).

For nonzero values of \epsilon and r the function h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is defined by h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(\ell+1-\kappa\right)}{\pi \kappa^{\ell}}\left(W_{\kappa,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(2r/\kappa\right)+(-1)^{ \ell}S(\epsilon,r)\frac{\Gamma\left(\ell+1+\kappa\right)}{2(2\ell+1)!}M_{ \kappa,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(2r/\kappa\right)\right), where \kappa is given by (LABEL:eq:CW.SOLrep.KAP) and S(\epsilon,r)=\begin{cases}2\cos\left(\pi|\epsilon|^{-1/2}\right),&\epsilon<0, r>0,\\ 0,&\epsilon<0,r<0,\\ e^{\pi\epsilon^{-1/2}},&\epsilon>0,r>0,\\ e^{-\pi\epsilon^{-1/2}},&\epsilon>0,r<0.\end{cases } (Again, the choice of the ambiguous sign in the last line of (LABEL:eq:CW.SOLrep.KAP) is immaterial.)
h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is real and an analytic function of each of r and \epsilon in the intervals -\infty<r<\infty and -\infty<\epsilon<\infty , except when r=0 or \epsilon=0.

The functions s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) and c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) are defined by s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=(B(\epsilon,\ell)/2)^{1/2}f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r \right), c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=(2B(\epsilon,\ell))^{-1/2}h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r \right), provided that \ell<(-\epsilon)^{-1/2} when \epsilon<0 , where B(\epsilon,\ell)=\begin{cases}A(\epsilon,\ell)\left(1-\exp\left(-2\pi/\epsilon ^{1/2}\right)\right)^{-1},&\epsilon>0,\\ A(\epsilon,\ell),&\epsilon\leq 0,\end{cases} and A(\epsilon,\ell)=\prod_{k=0}^{\ell}(1+\epsilon k^{2}).

An alternative formula for A(\epsilon,\ell) is A(\epsilon,\ell)=\frac{\Gamma\left(1+\ell+\kappa\right)}{\Gamma\left(\kappa- \ell\right)}\kappa^{-2\ell-1}, the choice of sign in the last line of (LABEL:eq:CW.SOLrep.KAP) again being immaterial.
When \epsilon<0 and \ell>(-\epsilon)^{-1/2} the quantity A(\epsilon,\ell) may be negative, causing s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) and c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) to become imaginary.

The function s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) has the following properties: \int_{0}^{\infty}s\left(\epsilon_{1},\ell;r\right)s\left(\epsilon_{2},\ell;r \right)\mathrm{d}r=\delta\left(\epsilon_{1}-\epsilon_{2}\right), where the right-hand side is the Dirac delta (§LABEL:sec:AL.RDF).

When \epsilon=-1/n^{2} , n=\ell+1,\ell+2,\dots , s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is \exp\left(-r/n\right) times a polynomial in r , and \phi_{n,\ell}(r)=(-1)^{\ell+1+n}(2/n^{3})^{1/2}s\left(-1/n^{2},\ell;r\right) satisfies \int_{0}^{\infty}\phi_{n,\ell}^{2}(r)\mathrm{d}r=1.
With arguments \epsilon,\ell,r suppressed, \mathscr{W}\left\{h,f\right\}=2/\pi, \mathscr{W}\left\{c,s\right\}=1/\pi.

para.sentence: With e denoting here the elementary charge, the Coulomb potential between two point particles with charges Z_{1}e,Z_{2}e and masses m_{1},m_{2} separated by a distance s is V(s)=Z_{1}Z_{2}e^{2}/(4\pi\varepsilon_{0}s)=Z_{1}Z_{2}\alpha\hbar c/s , where Z_{j} are atomic numbers, \varepsilon_{0} is the electric constant, \alpha is the fine structure constant, and \hbar is the reduced Planck’s constant.

The reduced mass is m=m_{1}m_{2}/(m_{1}+m_{2}) , and at energy of relative motion E with relative orbital angular momentum \ell\hbar , the Schrödinger equation for the radial wave function w(s) is given by \left(-\frac{\hbar^{2}}{2m}\left(\frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}}{{\mathrm{d}s}^{2}}- \frac{\ell(\ell+1)}{s^{2}}\right)+\frac{Z_{1}Z_{2}\alpha\hbar c}{s}\right)w=Ew,

With the substitutions {\sf k}=(2mE/\hbar^{2})^{1/2}, Z=mZ_{1}Z_{2}\alpha c/\hbar, x=s, (LABEL:eq:CW.APP.QM) becomes \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}x}^{2}}+\left({\sf k}^{2}-\frac{2Z}{x}- \frac{\ell(\ell+1)}{x^{2}}\right)w=0.
The {\sf k} -scaled variables \rho and \eta of §LABEL:sec:CW.EQ are given by \rho=s(2mE/\hbar^{2})^{1/2}, \eta=Z_{1}Z_{2}\alpha c(m/(2E))^{1/2}.
At positive energies E>0 , \rho\geq 0 , and:
Positive-energy functions correspond to processes such as Rutherford scatteringand Coulomb excitation of nuclei ( ( ) ), and atomic photo-ionization and electron-ion collisions ( ( ) ).
At negative energies E<0 and both \rho and \eta are purely imaginary.
The negative-energy functions are widely used in the description of atomic and molecular spectra; see ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .
In these applications, the Z -scaled variables r and \epsilon are more convenient.
The Z -scaled variables r and \epsilon of §LABEL:sec:CW.EQrep are given by r=-Z_{1}Z_{2}(mc\alpha/\hbar)s, \epsilon=E/(Z_{1}^{2}Z_{2}^{2}m{c^{2}}{\alpha^{2}}/2).
For Z_{1}Z_{2}=-1 and m=m_{e} , the electron mass, the scaling factors in (LABEL:eq:CW.APP.PHYSB) reduce to the Bohr radius, a_{0}=\hbar/(m_{e}c\alpha) , and to a multiple of the Rydberg constant,

Customary variables are (\epsilon,r) in atomic physics and (\eta,\rho) in atomic and nuclear physics.

The relativistic motion of spinless particles in a Coulomb field, as encountered in pionic atoms and pion-nucleon scattering ( ( ) ) is described by a Klein–Gordon equation equivalent to (LABEL:eq:CW.EQ.EQ); see ( ) .
The motion of a relativistic electron in a Coulomb field, which arises in the theory of the electronic structure of heavy elements ( ( ) ), is described by a Dirac equation.
The solutions to this equation are closely related to the Coulomb functions; see ( ) .
The Coulomb solutions of the Schrödinger and Klein–Gordon equations are almost always used in the external region, outside the range of any non-Coulomb forces or couplings.

For scattering problems, the interior solution is then matched to a linear combination of a pair of Coulomb functions, F_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) and G_{\ell}\left(\eta,\rho\right) , or f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) and h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) , to determine the scattering S -matrix and also the correct normalization of the interior wave solutions; see ( ) .
For bound-state problems only the exponentially decaying solution is required, usually taken to be the Whittaker function W_{-\eta,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(2\rho\right).

The functions \phi_{n,\ell}(r) defined by (LABEL:eq:CW.SOLrep.SP1) are the hydrogenic bound states in attractive Coulomb potentials; their polynomial components are often calledassociated Laguerre functions; see ( ) and ( ) .

The penetrability of repulsive Coulomb potential barriers is normally expressed in terms of the quantity \rho/({F_{\ell}^{2}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)+{G_{\ell}^{2}}\left(\eta,\rho\right)) ( ( , pp. 63–65) ).
The WKBJ approximations of §LABEL:sec:CW.METH.APP may also be used to estimate the penetrability.

The Coulomb functions given in this chapter are most commonly evaluated for real values of \rho , r , \eta , \epsilon and nonnegative integer values of \ell , but they may be continued analytically to complex arguments and order \ell as indicated in §LABEL:sec:CW.COM.
Examples of applications to noninteger and/or complex variables are as follows.

subsection.title: Methods for the Confluent Hypergeometric Functions

para.sentence: The methods used for computing the Coulomb functions described below are similar to those in §LABEL:sec:CH.CO.

The power-series expansions of §§LABEL:sec:CW.PRHO and LABEL:sec:CW.SERrep converge for all finite values of the radii \rho and r , respectively, and may be used to compute the regular and irregular solutions.
Cancellation errors increase with increases in \rho and |r| , and may be estimated by comparing the final sum of the series with the largest partial sum.

Use of extended-precision arithmetic increases the radial range that yields accurate results, but eventually other methods must be employed, for example, the asymptotic expansions of §§LABEL:sec:CW.ASY and LABEL:sec:CW.AFrep.

When numerical values of the Coulomb functions are available for some radii, their values for other radii may be obtained by direct numerical integration of equations (LABEL:eq:CW.EQ.EQ) or (LABEL:eq:CW.EQrep.EQ), provided that the integration is carried out in a stable direction (§LABEL:sec:NM.ODE).

Thus the regular solutions can be computed from the power-series expansions (§§LABEL:sec:CW.PRHO, LABEL:sec:CW.SERrep) for small values of the radii and then integrated in the direction of increasing values of the radii.

On the other hand, the irregular solutions of §§LABEL:sec:CW.SOL.IR andLABEL:sec:CW.SOLrep.IR need to be integrated in the direction of decreasing radii beginning, for example, with values obtained from asymptotic expansions (§§LABEL:sec:CW.ASY and LABEL:sec:CW.AFrep).

In a similar manner to §LABEL:sec:CW.METH.RI the recurrence relations of §§LABEL:sec:CW.RR or LABEL:sec:CW.RRrep can be used for a range of values of the integer \ell , provided that the recurrence is carried out in a stable direction (§LABEL:sec:NM.LDE).
This implies decreasing \ell for the regular solutions and increasing \ell for the irregular solutions of §§LABEL:sec:CW.SOL.IR and LABEL:sec:CW.SOLrep.IR.
